Today we celebrate a day to remember and honor the lost souls who fought and stood up for the basic rights to be transgender. Their voices and lasting impact has made our LQBTIQ community stronger and a little more heard and accepted. We will always be grateful for the changes they made. 

Take a minute and send a little prayer to our lost but fearless transgender individuals.

NO LONGER INVISIBLE! 

On this Lesbian Visibility Day, we want to reiterate that all lesbian identities and relationships - whether you are a butch lesbian, fem lesbian, trans lesbian, a non-binary lesbian, or a lesbian who doesn't subscribe to labels - you are all valid and loved. We are proud to celebrate you and support you today and every day! 

Happy Lesbian Visibility Day 2021! 

To celebrate, we ask you to join us by participating in this:
If you could write a song about a lesbian love story, what is the first verse?

Transgender day of remembrance is a day that honors the memory of the lives lost due to transphobia and violence. 
Transgender Day of Remembrance raises public awareness of hate crimes against transgenders and honors the lives of transgenders who might otherwise be forgotten.

A bisexual person is someone who experiences multi-gender attraction; they might be physically, emotionally and/or spiritually attracted to men, women, and non-binary persons.

According to EQUAL GROUNDтАЩs research, while 12% of Sri LankaтАЩs population belong to the LGBTIQ community, 8% identify as bisexual.  

Unfortunately, even within the LGBTIQ community, bisexual persons experience rejection, discrimination, lack of support, and invisibility. Therefore, many issues and challenges faced by bisexual persons are not properly addressed.

On this Bi-Visibility Day, we encourage you to proudly embrace your authentic self and celebrate yourself, no matter who you are attracted to/love. EQUAL GROUND is here to support you always.

EQUAL GROUND is proud to celebrate its 18th anniversary today! Since 2004, we have weathered many storms, but we have grown from strength to strength, despite the many challenges thrown our way. We have and will always stand with the LGBTIQ community and continue to advocate for equality and human rights for all. Thank you to everyone who has stood with us in love and solidarity and supported our work!

On International Transgender Day of Visibility we celebrate the resilience and strength of Sri LankaтАЩs transgender community, while recognizing the many challenges they face. Schools, workplaces, healthcare institutions, and public spaces are some of the places where trans people face the most discrimination and harassment. While Sri Lanka has some policies to help the transgender community, we have a long way to go. LetтАЩs pledge to bridge these policy gaps and help make everyone feel safe and valued!

2023 -08-08 

Another victory for democracy

The Speaker announces to the Parliament the Supreme Court decision on the petition against the amendment proposed to the Local Government Ordinance by Jayantha Katagoda MP. 

Today (8th August), the Speaker announced   to the parliament  the decision of the Supreme Court on the petition  filed by PAFFREL and several other parties against the  Local Governments Amendments bills   presented  to the Parliament by Jayantha Katagoda,  MP,  to  reinstate  the former Councilors  of the  dissolved LG bodies.Mr. Rohana Rohana Hettiarachchi, Executive Director, PAFFREL represented the PAFFREL in filing the petition. 

The PAFFREL has repeatedly expressed its protest against the people's representatives holding to their office beyond the limit they were elected for by the people and the Councilors acting in an arbitrary and undemocratic manner. This petition bearing the number SC (SD) NO 25/2023 was filed on the 12th July making Mr. Jayantha Katagoda MP and the Attorney General the respondents of the case. 

The decision  of the Supreme Court on this petition which has been referred to the Honorable Speaker today (August 8, 2023) was announced to the Parliament by the Hon Speaker  and the  latter  stated that the Clause 2 of all  three amendments proposed namely the  "Pradeshiya Sabha Act (Amendment)",тАЬUrban Councils Ordinance (Amendment)тАЭ and "Municipal Councils Ordinance (Amendment)" which were challenged before the Supreme Court is  inconsistent with  Articles  1, 12 (1), 82, 83 and  104B  of the Constitution, and therefore the Supreme Court has decided that all three bills pertain to the "Pradeshiya Sabha Act (Amendment)",тАЬUrban Councils Ordinance (Amendment)тАЭ and "Municipal Councils Ordinance (Amendment)" should be passed by special majority vote of the Parliament and also  approved by the people in a referendum according to the provisions of Article 83 of the Constitution. 

This judgment is a great victory achieved in recent history by the people who value democracy in Sri Lanka. Also it is envisaged to achieve similar victories in respect of the other petitions filed by the Paffrel and other parties in the Supreme Court in relation to the postponement of local government elections arbitrarily. Despite there has been a recent tendency among politicians to abuse parliamentary power and undermine democratic values to consolidate their power, this judgment emphasizes that such practices could not be continued any longer.

Rohana Hettiarachchi
Executive Director

#NewsUpdate #SLPolitics #LGPolls #rohanahettiarachchi #PAFFREL

Is it a crime to be LGBTIQ in Sri Lanka? 
Sections 365 and 365A of Sri LankaтАЩs Penal Code criminalises тАЬcarnal intercourse against the order of natureтАЭ and тАЬgross indecencyтАЭ. Thanks to their colonial legacy, these laws are used against the LGBTIQ community. But, diverse Sexual Orientations and/or Gender Identities/Expressions (SOGIE) are not outlawed. Fundamental rights recognised by the Sri Lankan constitution include non-discrimination under article 12(2). On several occasions, the Sri Lankan government has said that LGBTIQ persons are constitutionally protected, and non-discrimination on Sexual Orientation and/or Gender Identity/Expression is implicitly included under this constitutional provision.

Economic Recovery Hinges on inclusive Democracy: A strong call for action by the Civil Society Collective for Democracy.

The Civil Society Collective for Democracy, also known by its slogan тАШStand for DemocracyтАЩ, a coalition of concerned citizens and organizations, including civil society organizations, professionals, academics, trade unions, youth leaders, activists, media personnel, religious figures, and other influencers, convened today at the Sri Lanka Foundation Institute (SLFI) to deliver a crucial wake-up call to the nation's political leaders. The urgent call is to halt state repression and safeguard the democratic rights of the people, in order to ensure actual and equitable economic recovery.

The Civil Society Collective expresses deep concern over the rapid shrinking of democratic space within the country, with Constitutionally guaranteed rights and freedoms such as the freedom of expression, right to information, right to dissent, right to protest, freedom of association and the right to franchise being snatched away, leaving citizens often powerless. This surge in silencing voices and the targeting and harassment of those who question the authorities, have created a chilling effect among the people, leading to self-censorship. Furthermore, the rulers have been abusing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and the contentious Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) to target political opponents, civil society activists, and journalists, contrary to international commitments, including those made at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC). The recent attempts to introduce extremely oppressive versions of laws such as the Anti-Terrorism Act, Broadcasting Commission Act and the NGO Act are examples of GovernmentтАЩs attempt to threaten and control democratic space.  

Recent statements from the President, the Speaker and even few parliamentarians that attempt to undermine judicial independence are deeply troubling. While the 21st Amendment to the Constitution has re-established the independent commissions, the recent acts of intimidation targeting members of the Election Commission and the Public Utilities Commission are examples of the disabling environment that has been created for these institutions. At the heart of the matter, citizens' sovereign right to vote has been infringed upon using financial constraints as an excuse, an explanation lacking credibility. Currently Sri Lankans have no elected representatives at local and provincial levels and these institutions are governed by unelected officials controlled by a centralised executive. This if not addressed soon may call into question the definition of Sri Lanka as a democracy.

To uplift Sri Lanka from the economic crisis, it is essential to address its root causes - poor governance, lack of inclusivity and corruption. Unless these fundamental issues are addressed, Sri Lanka will continue to be considered as a complex investment context that will discourage investors and thus hamper economic recovery.
 
Ensuring transparency and accountability in governance is essential to prevent corruption and to ensure good governance. For people to be able to hold their representatives and the stewards of public resources accountable, they need to be able to exercise their democratic rights and freedoms. A truly democratic system would enable citizens to elect and vote out their representatives regularly, be involved and informed of all GovernmentтАЩs decisions that affect their lives, be able to dissent and make their voices heard in protest and be able to form collectives and exert pressure on the authorities to change course when necessary.

A government that acts in the best interest of the people and is genuine in its effort to uplift the economy will not hesitate to expose themselves to public scrutiny.  

In line with these principles, the Civil Society Collective for Democracy calls upon the political establishment to take immediate steps to uphold and defend the foundational principles of democracy by:  
 
- Ensuring that free and fair elections essential for inclusion are held on time, starting immediately with the Local Government and Provincial Council Elections.  
- Uphold the fundamental rights of citizens, including freedom of expression and association and right to information.  
- Protect civic space and create an enabling environment for civil society activism.  
- Ensure citizen consultation and participation in steering economic recovery.
- Govern with transparency and accountability, ensuring full public scrutiny.  
- Empower the independent commissions to fulfill their roles effectively.
- Take a genuine effort to implement essential anti-corruption reforms.
-Take action to prosecute past and present acts of corruption to end the climate of impunity.

#StandForDemocracy

Breast Cancer Awareness Month - October 2022
ЁЯМИЁЯТЯЁЯМ╖ЁЯл╢

Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers among women worldwide. It is one of the leading health crises for women in Sri Lanka and in 2019, 4447 new cases of breast cancer were reported. Screening does not ensure breast cancer prevention, but helps to start treatment early when diagnosed. 
Did you know that men can also develop breast cancer, although rarely. Sri Lanka reported a total of 113 males diagnosed with breast cancer in 2019. 
October has been designated as the Pink Month and throughout this month we aim to educate and raise awareness on breast cancer.  Use this Breast Cancer Awareness Month to  increase support for awareness, early detection, and treatment.

https://tamil.adaderana.lk/news.php?nid=170791

EQUAL GROUND established in 2004, celebrates 19 years of activism to advocate for the lives of the LGBTIQ community in Sri Lanka.  #ColomboPRIDE is its flagship event held every year since 2004 - without pause!  Even COVID did not stop us! We celebrate our 19 years! We celebrate that our Abhimani Queer Film Festival is the oldest such festival in South Asia!
And we celebrate how much we have achieved in these 19 years!  We hope that even before we celebrate our 20th Year, we would achieve the icing on the cake - decriminalization!  We are thankful to everyone who has been with us on this journey - our Trustees, our Staff, our donors, LGBTIQ community members, our Allies and friends, the diplomatic community, the media and many others - too many to mention!  

Happy Pride!

EQUAL GROUND Case Update as of 16th September 2022;

-Case filed against Ama Dissanayake and Sri Lanka Police postponed-

The case filed by Rosanna Flamer-Caldera and 9 others against the Sri Lanka Police and purported mental health counselor Ama Dissanayake in the Court of Appeal was postponed, yet again, on 16 September 2022 as the State supposedly required an additional period of two months to consider the terms proposed by the petitioners of the case. 

The petition was filed in September 2021 in the Court of Appeals against the conduct of the Sri Lanka Police for contracting Dissanayake to train police officers, during which Dissanayake is seen and heard to make derogatory and false statements against  the LGBTIQ community.

After one year the case has not come to a conclusion nor has the Sri Lanka Police attempted to take into consideration the petitionerтАЩs proposals where they require an undertaking from the Police to no longer conduct any programs discriminating and villyfying the LGBTIQ community. The police have also wasted the courtтАЩs time by not being present for several of the many dates set by the court, even after being duly notified, to give reasons as to their above conduct.  This indicates the lack of concern on the part of the police and clear disregard for the valuable time of the court and resources of the parties involved. 

Despite a pending case against her actions, Dissanayake was also seen just last week delivering a speech at an event hosted by the Sri Lanka Police in lieu of celebrating their 156th anniversary.

#16DaysofActivism #accesstohealthcare #LGBTIQcommunity #safemedicine #equalhealthcareaccess #HIVAIDS

This statement is to address the erroneous Tweets and Facebook posts with regard to EQUAL GROUNDтАЩs Colombo PRIDE Walk. Sadly, the context of our Executive Director-Rosanna Flamer-CalderaтАЩs quote given to The Morning has been largely misinterpreted and been used out of context.

We understand and accept that everyone has the right to protest and respect their freedom of expression, and we certainly are not denying it. The Colombo PRIDE Walk is not a platform for anti-governmental action as we need to keep in mind that we are on the verge of decriminalization of same-sex relationships between consenting adults and should not do anything to jeopardize a process that was started many years ago.  As an organization we have been protesting against discrimination and standing up for LGBTIQ rights for 19 years now while also pressing for decriminalization, both in Sri Lanka and abroad.

Moreover, EQUAL GROUND was always supportive of the Aragalaya and its trustees and employees were actively a part of it last year. We are not discrediting the spirit of the Aragalaya or its purpose nor its participants! We also have not forgotten history and the Stonewall Riots that have led to PRIDE celebrations world wide!

We are simply inviting everyone to come join us at a peaceful walk to celebrate PRIDE and we are happy to inform everyone that we have the necessary permissions for this and will be joined by foreign dignitaries, LGBTIQ community members, friends and allies. On this day for women, we celebrate all women in social, economic, political spheres  who continue to achieve and accomplish against all odds and differences. More than 1/3rd of women in the world experience online gender based violence. It is also the second biggest form of gender based violence in Sri Lanka. 

Exploring the theme тАШDigitALL: Innovation and technology for gender equalityтАЩ EQUAL GROUND would like to highlight the importance of digital literacy of women in protecting their rights and creating a safe space for them.

#16DaysOfActivism Day 07:

World AIDS Day 2022

Did you know?? 4686 HIV cases were reported in Sri Lanka at the end of the 3rd quarter (June 2022), as per the National STD/AIDS Control Programme data. Out of this, 3377 were men while 1309 were women and 25 deaths were reported among them.  

Get yourself tested at the nearest local STD clinic.

International Day of Social Justice 2023

Today we celebrate a day geared towards uplifting and promoting efforts fighting for equality and social justice in all walks of life! We commit to work together to build bridges and allyship for the goal of a fair and just society - accepting all genders, orientations, faiths, races, ethnicities and differences.

Let us join the fight for equal rights, fairness and justice for all!

Celebrating Lesbian Visibility Day Sri Lanka 2022!
#LVDSL2022  #LVD2022 #LesbianVisibilityDaySL 

Sri Lankan Lesbian Women rising up to claim their legal rights 

1. A case was filed against a lesbian woman by her parents seeking a court declaration that their daughter was mentally ill due to her sexual orientation, being a lesbian. The court later dismissed the application. 
Read full story here: https://www.newswire.lk/2022/08/02/wattala-court-dismisses-case-filed-against-a-lesbian/ via NEWSWIRE 02 August 2022

The woman was later granted interim protection against her abusive parents by the Kaduwela Magistrate. This is the first time such an order was granted by a court of law. 
Read full story here: https://www.dailymirror.lk/latest_news/Court-grants-interim-protection-to-lesbian-from-abusive-parents/342-243939 via DailyMirror 29 August 2022

2. In the first international case on lesbian criminalisation;  Rosanna Flamer-Caldera vs. Sri Lanka (CEDAW 2022) - the UN WomenтАЩs Right Committee found that the criminalisation of consensual, same-sex intimacy between women is a human rights violation.
Read full decision here: https://docstore.ohchr.org/SelfServices/FilesHandler.ashx?enc=6QkG1d%2fPPRiCAqhKb7yhsgekS3XMuMTIW18D8vtwB3%2b8OowwLQYQf%2fxhBgOcu5D8ukESSYyyM65DNEOv8ZoRt9eGdAUtUGXxzO4%2f8w0r66So1DxuTPKxQ%2fKRx8t0RRbhG3hR0MHEjiLIQML6Eugy6w%3d%3d

Also see: https://ohrh.law.ox.ac.uk/rosanna-flamer-caldera-v-sri-lanka-cedaw-2022-the-first-international-case-on-lesbian-criminalisation/ and https://www.humandignitytrust.org/news/un-committee-rules-that-criminalisation-of-same-sex-intimacy-between-women-is-a-human-rights-violation/ via Human Dignity Trust 23 March 2022

EQUAL GROUND Case Update as of 10th January 2023:

-Case filed against Ama Dissanayake and Sri Lanka Police-

The Deputy Solicitor General (DSG) appearing on behalf of the Sri Lanka Police in the case filed by EQUAL GROUND and Others against Ama Dissanayake and the former, tendered to court today a copy of a circular drafted with instructions to be followed by police officers with regard to the LGBTIQ community. The DSG further stated that the said Circular bearing No. 2740/22 dated 27.12.2022 has already been circulated among senior officers of the Sri Lanka Police. 

The learned Counsel for the Petitioners Presidents Counsel Mr. Sanjeewa Jayawardena was also handed over a copy of the circular and he subsequently informed court that he requires time to consult with the petitioners and inform court their stance. Mr. Jayawardena reiterated to court that the circular need to be more specific with regard to the prohibition adopted against purported counsellor Ama Dissanayake where she cannot be invited by the Police for any sort of lectures and further the circular to be applied equally to all that resort to label the LGBTIQ community as perpetrators. 

In September 2021, EQUAL GROUND executive director Rosanna Flamer-Caldera along with nine others filed a petition to the Court of Appeal seeking a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Prohibition against the Sri Lanka Police in facilitating the conduct of training sessions by Ama Dissanayake or any such programmes that discriminates or makes remarks that are erroneous towards the LGBTIQ community.

#16DaysofActivism Norwegian Embassy in Colombo Shanthi Maargam

Zero Discrimination Day 2023

We celebrate the right of everyone to live a full and productive life - and live it with dignity. Zero Discrimination Day highlights how people can become informed about and promote inclusion, compassion, peace and, above all, a movement for change. Today is about helping to create a global movement of solidarity to end all forms of discrimination. 

We especially highlight the recent victory in legally mitigating Police discrimination against the Trans community and hope to spread the same change towards all queer persons in Sri Lanka!

More reading: https://www.dailymirror.lk/news-features/Today-is-Zero-Discrimination-Day-Decriminalising-homosexuality-What-this-means-for-Sri-Lanka/131-255025

Today we celebrate International Non-Binary People's Day aimed at raising awareness around the issues faced by non-binary people around the world! 
Nonbinary is an adjective used by people who experience their gender identity and/or gender expression as falling outside the binary gender categories of man and woman.
Even though being non-binary is dismissed by some as a new western born identity-obsessed culture, there are records in history where being non-binary is celebrated all around the globe. In India non-binary people have been mentioned in Hindu texts dating back over 2000 years, and many cultures, such as some Native American peoples, Hawaiians, and Tahitians, have a history of inclusion of a third gender in their societiesтАЩ roles. Few countries, such as Australia, Germany, India, and Canada do recognise Non Binary as a gender. 
While Non Binary individuals use they/them pronouns some also prefer other gender-neutral pronouns, as well as gendered pronouns. 
You can take the first step towards being an ally by asking for their preferred pronouns!

родрооро┐ро┤ройрпН роЪрпЖропрпНродро┐роХро│рпН

EQUAL GROUND condemns the recent arrest in Akkaraipattu, of two women, who are claimed to have engaged in a same sex relationship. 

The arbitrary arrests of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual Transgender, Intersex, and Queer/Questioning (LGBTIQ) persons severely impedes their basic human rights. 

The UN Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW) recently found that the criminalisation of consensual, same-sex relations between women in Sri Lanka is a human rights violation. The CEDAW Committee said that section 365A of the Penal Code of 1883 (amended in 1995) that criminalises same sex sexual relations between consenting adults compounds discrimination against women in Sri Lanka, and as such, violates lesbian and bisexual womenтАЩs right to non-discrimination under article 2 (a) and (d)тАУ(g) of the Convention. It also noted that that decriminalization of consensual same-sex relations is essential to prevent and protect against violence, discrimination and harmful gender stereotypes.

Globally, it has been accepted that being LGBTIQ is not unnatural, deviant, or a deserving of punishment or harassment. Further, the world of psychiatry and medical bodies have largely accepted that diverse Sexual Orientations and Gender Identities/Expressions (SOGIE) are not mental or physical illnesses. The World Medical Association (WMA) has strongly emphasised тАЬthat homosexuality does not represent a disease, but a normal variation within the realm of human sexuality.тАЭ The World Health OrganisationтАЩs (WHO), International Classification of Diseases (ICD) removed homosexuality from its list of diseases in 1990 and states that тАЬsexual orientation by itself is not to be considered a disorderтАЭ. Locally, the Sri Lanka College of Psychiatrists has echoed similar sentiments. In a statement last year, they said modern-day psychiatrists do not identify homosexuality as a mental illness or treat it as such and called the governmemt to decriminalise homosexual relations. 

Considering this, EQUAL GROUND urges Sri Lanka to take immediate and decisive steps to repeal Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code and decriminalise same sex sexual relations in Sri Lanka.

Breast Cancer Awareness Month - October 2022
ЁЯМИЁЯТЯЁЯМ╖ЁЯл╢

Breast Cancer in Men;
Globally, on average, 1 out of 1000 men develop breast cancer and men have a higher mortality rate than women due to lack of awareness.

The most common symptoms of breast cancer in men areтАФ
тЪбя╕П A lump or swelling in the breast.
тЪбя╕П Redness or flaky skin in the breast.
тЪбя╕П Dimpling of breast skin.
тЪбя╕П Nipple discharge.
тЪбя╕П Pulling in of the nipple or pain in the nipple area.
These symptoms can happen with other conditions that are not cancer. If you have any symptoms or changes, see your doctor right away.

EQUAL GROUND thanks the Sri Lanka College of Psychiatrists (SLCP) for responding to our letter and taking prompt action with regard to individuals spreading erroneous and harmful messages regarding the LGBTIQ community. We appreciate SLCP calling on the authorities to repeal Article 365 of the Sri Lanka Penal Code that criminalises same sex sexual relationships between consenting adults. We would also like to reiterate that diverse Sexual Orientations and Gender Identities/Expressions are NOT considered mental illnesses or unnatural/deviant behaviour.

ЁЯП│я╕ПтАНЁЯМИ We celebrate PRIDE 2023 by showcasing the creative talents of our community - EQUAL GROUND is proud to present the Art and Photo Exhibition! ЁЯП│я╕ПтАНЁЯМИ

If you are an aspiring artist, cartoonist or photographer, we encourage you to display your creations and take part in a chance to network with the Art community. Creatives will have the opportunity to put up their work for sale to any interested parties. The exhibition hopes to launch along with a reception at which local art collectors, professionals and galleries will be in attendance. All participants will be able to take part in prizes for Best Artwork, Best Photography and Best Cartoon/Comic strip!

Note: NO professional artists are eligible for prizes. Amateur and aspiring creatives are encouraged to participate in this platform. 

Check out the guidelines below and DM us if you need any further info! We look forward to seeing your creativity shine!

#PRIDEMONTH #Gratitude #LoveIsLove #TogetherWeRise #ColomboPride2023

SPIRIT DAY! ЁЯМИЁЯМ║ЁЯТЯЁЯл╢

Spirit day is a day that aims to raise awareness regarding the bullying and harassment that LGBTIQ individuals face due to their sexual orientation, gender identity, expression and sex characteristics.  Over the years it has grown in popularity and visibility and the color purple is used to show support to the LGBTIQ community and to honor the communityтАЩs suicide victims.
There are still  69 countries around the world including Sri Lanka that criminalizes same-sex relationships. Close to 80% of LGBTIQ people across the world report social isolation and one in five people of the LGBTIQ community has experienced a hate crime because of their sexual orientation or gender identity, expression or sex characteristics.

Come join us united in solidarity and take a stance against bullying and harassment.

#lgbt #spiritday #antibullying #lbtiq #community #genderidentity #orientation ##lgbtbullying #pride #loveislove #spirit #queer

Breast Cancer Awareness Month - October 2022
ЁЯМИЁЯТЯЁЯМ╖ЁЯл╢

Symptoms of Breast Cancer : 
Different people have different symptoms of breast cancer. Some people do not have any signs or symptoms at all. 
Some warning signs of breast cancer areтАФ

ЁЯеА New lump in the breast or underarm (armpit)
ЁЯеА Thickening or swelling of part of the breast
ЁЯеА Dimpling of breast skin
ЁЯеА Redness or flaky skin in the nipple area or the breast
ЁЯеА Pulling in of the nipple or pain in the nipple area
ЁЯеА Nipple discharge other than breast milk, including blood
ЁЯеА Any change in the size or the shape of the breast
ЁЯеА Pain in any area of the breast

**Keep in mind that these symptoms can happen with other conditions that are not cancer.
If you have any signs or symptoms that worry you, be sure to see your doctor right away.

National Transgender Network Sri Lanka John Keells Holdings PLC Bridge to Equality - р╖Гр╢╕р╖Пр╢▒р╖Пр╢нр╖Кр╢╕р╢нр╖Пр╖Ар╢║ р╖Гр╖Ьр╢║р╖П - роЪроородрпНродрпБро╡родрпНродрпИ родрпЗроЯрпБродро▓рпН Sugar Beach Heart to Heart Sri lanka Organization Women's Solidarity Network Live with Love Young Activist Collective

During a meeting held at the Sri Lanka Police Headquarters on Friday (9th December) between the Inspector General of Police (IGP), senior police officials and representatives of LGBTIQ organizations, IGP C. D. Wickramaratne apologized for the longstanding harassment faced by the LGBTIQ community at the hands of the police. 

The meeting, organized by the Ministry of Women, Child Affairs and Social  Empowerment and the Sri Lanka Police, discussed the way forward towards treating all human beings equally and without discrimination.

EQUAL GROUND wishes to clarify the misinformation regarding the Writ petition filed against the Police and Ama Dissanayake. In September 2021 EG, initiated legal action in the Court of Appeal, seeking a mandate in the nature of a Writ of Prohibition against the police and Ama Disanayake for conducting a training programme for the police where malicious, erroneous, and discriminatory remarks were made about the LGBTIQ community. In November 2021, the Court granted permission to EG to serve notice to the respondents. On 08 December 2021, the Court of Appeal granted leave to proceed to the merit stage with the EQUAL GROUND petition and ordered notice be issued to all parties. On the same day, Three intervenient petitioners also sought to be added to EGтАЩs petition based on the fact that they are interested parties as they are from the LGBTIQ community. The court ordered them to be added as respondents as they seem to have sufficient interest and are prima facie affected by the matter. While we appreciate the support extended, we would like to clarify that this is a case filed by EG with 07 of our supportive allies whom we are very grateful for. We would appreciate if interested parties intervening, do so with of bona fide intention of being a supporter to EG and not merely to add names to this historic case of EG. We are obliged to make this statement observing recent heightened social media activities and inquiries we have received about our case while any online support and activity was absent prior to 08th December 2021. We would like to reiterate that this is a milestone for the whole of LGBTIQ community and all well intended support is welcome.

LGBTIQ+ individuals are criminalized in approximately 67 countries worldwide. This in turn results in prosecution, incarceration and human rights violations of LGBTIQ+ individuals. This not only affects the LGBTIQ+ community but also can cause dire consequences and negatively impact countries throughout the world, hindering their economic growth and development. 

Refer to the link in bio to read more on this research.

SHORT FILM COMPETITION

Calling all aspiring filmmakers! If you have a knack for storytelling and visual representation, we invite you to participate in this year's PRIDE short film competition 2023!

Submit your original work that brings to light stories from our community that need to be told;

ЁЯП│я╕ПтАНЁЯМИEntries through any other social media app such as Whatsapp, Messenger, Viber etc, will not be considered for the competition.
ЁЯП│я╕ПтАНЁЯМИEG reserves the right to reject any submission without reason. Please refrain from using nudity or profanity in your work.

A slew of erroneous and harmful statements about the LGBTIQ community has been brought to light recently. One of the most common myths is that being LGBTIQ was unnatural and deviant social behaviour. There have also been claims that being LGBTIQ is a mental illness. 
The truth is international psychaitric and medical bodies, such as The World Health Organisation (WHO) and the World Medical Association (WMA) have largely accepted that diverse Sexual Orientations and Gender Identities/Expressions (SOGIE) are not mental or physical illnesses. The Diagnostic Statistics Manual (DSM) published by the American Psychiatric Association (APA) тАУ the standard classification of mental disorders тАУ removed the diagnosis of тАЬhomosexualityтАЭ from its second edition (DSM II) in 1973 тАУ nearly half a century ago.

LGBTIQ+ individuals are criminalized in approximately 67 countries worldwide. This in turn results in prosecution, incarceration and human rights violations of LGBTIQ+ individuals. This not only affects the LGBTIQ+ community but also can cause dire consequences and negatively impact countries throughout the world, hindering their economic growth and development. 

Refer to the link in bio to read more on this research.

EQUAL GROUND welcomes the Private Member Bill brought forward by MP Premnath C. Dolawatte to amend the Penal Code to decriminalise same sex sexual relations between consenting adults. We hope the Parliament and President take decisive action in this regard to remove laws that marginalise the LGBTIQ community and violate their rights.

We dedicate today to celebrate the Trans community and Non-Binary persons in the world and to raise awareness on the discrimination and harassment faced by them. It is important to learn and listen to their voices to understand the diversity of the community and to become a better ally who stands with them. 

We also highlight the Police Circular that came about this year as a result of EQUAL GROUNDтАЩs court case - which includes guidelines taking into account the harassment faced by the trans community in Sri Lanka each day. 

As a community we look forward towards the legal reforms to take place and result in the repeal of discriminatory penal laws in Sri Lanka.

Another common claim made by certain medical professionals is that non-heteronormative SOGIE (such as homosexuality and trans-sexuality) can be cured. However, since non-heteronormative sexual orientations and gender identities are not considered as mental or physical illnesses or disorders, there is nothing to cure or correct. In other words, all Sexual Orientations and Gender Identities/Expressions are natural and valid. Conversion and correction therapies are considered pseudoscientific practices and are widely discredited in the medical field. Also, there are no credible scientific studies that prove that conversion therapy is effective in any way.

LGBTIQ+ individuals are criminalized in approximately 67 countries worldwide. This in turn results in prosecution, incarceration and human rights violations of LGBTIQ+ individuals. This not only affects the LGBTIQ+ community but also can cause dire consequences and negatively impact countries throughout the world, hindering their economic growth and development.

Rohana Hettiarachchi

Lesbian Visibility Day is an important event in the LGBTIQ+ community, to recognise the contributions and accomplishments of lesbians, and to raise awareness about the challenges they face. This day marks an important step in the fight for lesbian rights and recognition, and it is an opportunity to honor and acknowledge them.

2023.01.17                                                             LG/EC/2023/003  
                                                                                                           
Mr. Nimal Punchiheva,
Chairman,
Election Commission,
Rajagiriya

Mr. Chairman,

Use of public resources and property owned by local authorities for political purposes.

Complaints regarding the use of public property namely the office vehicles, development projects, welfare projects and projects openings etc. by the heads of local government bodies ostensibly for the promotion of the interests of their respective  political  parties  and prospective candidates including themselves are being received  from the time the local government election was  announced. From a technical point of view   they are not election candidates at the moment, but it is natural and most likely for them to become the candidates in the upcoming election. 

Also, there is a high risk that they might continue to use the resources and property belongs to their institutions until the end of the election. Hence, this situation should be controlled forthwith. Otherwise the equal ground of election will be lost.

Therefore, we kindly request you to make the Local Government secretaries, Municipal Commissioners and Local Government Commissioners aware of this situation, and advise them to initiate necessary steps to prevent the  use  of resources and property belong to local government bodies for the   promotion of the  interests of political parties or candidates,  and prepare the necessary environment  for a free and fair election.

Thank you 

Rohana Hettiarachchi
Executive Director

Even though 12% of the country's adult population identifies as LGBTIQ, Sri Lanka still has archaic laws in place - particularly Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code - that discriminate against the LGBTIQ community. 
On this Zero Discrimination Day, we highlight the right of everyone, including the LGBTIQ community, to live a full and productive life, with dignity. 
Let's pledge to end inequalities and discrimination based on sexual orientations and gender identities/expressions.

APCOM Foundation, a leading Asia Pacific LGBTQI and HIV community organisation based in Bangkok, partnered with ILGA Asia and APN+ for their annual HERO awards. This yearтАЩs honorees for Community Hero and HIV Hero categories under the theme "Unity and Diversity" was announced on the 15th of November.

We are proud to announce that Rosanna Flamer-Caldera, Executive Director of EQUAL GROUND has been selected for one of three, for the Community Hero Award!

We also congratulate Thelge Tiran Daison Edward Peiris, on his nomination as an HIV HERO for his long-standing activism for the welfare of PLHIV and LGBTQI in Sri Lanka.

CALL FOR AUDITIONS!
EQUAL GROUND is looking for actors and dancers from the LGBTIQ community in Sri Lanka to appear in a local music video project that will be also viewed internationally. 

Requirements: 
Needs to be from the LGBTIQ community and be open (as you will appear in the video).
You will be paid LKR 5,000 for your participation. 
You need to be able to commit your time and be available for the video shoot (1-2 days). 
You should sign a disclaimer if chosen. 
Once the video has been shot, we cannot make changes - so if you agree to participate, you cannot remove yourself once the shoot is completed. 

Sinhala and Tamil speakers are encouraged to audition. 
To apply, email your photo  and a bio to media@equalgroundsrilanka.com by 10 AUGUST 2021. 
Video will be shot with all health precautions in place.

FREE COUNSELLING SERVICES FOR THE LGBTIQ COMMUNITY

Provided by: Ms. Sithara Hansini 
Open via email: sitharahansinicounselling@outlook.com
Available for counselling Every Saturday & Sunday 9.30 am - 4.30am (SL Time)
LGBTIQ persons between the age of 18 - 27 years 

About the counsellor: Sithara Hansini has a Bachelors of Arts major in Psychology and a Masters in Counselling. She has experience working as a support worker in an institute with mentally and physically disabled individuals. In Melbourne she has worked as a school counsellor for students in a secondary school (students aged between 13-19). She mainly provides art therapy, solution focused therapy, person centered approach and mindfulness exercise. She has worked in LGBTQ+ club in school and discussed different issues they are facing. Sithara is a member of Australian Counselling Association.

CELEBRATING PRIDE MONTH!

EQUAL GROUND IS 17 YEARS OLD!

Since our inception on 10 June 2004, EQUAL GROUND has been working tirelessly to advance the rights of Sri LankaтАЩs LGBTIQ community.

A look back at our journey:

- EQUAL GROUND is the oldest and one of the only advocacy organisations to work for the rights of the diverse spectrum of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer/questioning people, together with allies.

- We work across Sri Lanka and have covered more than 20 districts.

- EQUAL GROUND works in Sinhala, Tamil, and English, so our initiatives are accessible to all communities in Sri Lanka.

- EQUAL GROUND's Leadership is one of a kind -  we are the only LGBTIQ organisation in Sri Lanka led by lesbian women.

- Our ground-breaking initiatives include Colombo PRIDE celebrations, the ally network (Friends and Family of LGBTIQ тАУ FFLGBTIQ), the first LGBTIQ-friendly career website (http://www.dedunusawiya.com/), Abhimani Queer Film Festival, D&I Programs focusing on LGBTIQ in the workplace, and many more.

- weтАЩve conducted Ground-breaking research - including Sri Lanka's first study mapping LGBTIQ identities and Workplace discrimination 

- WeтАЩve Created the first LGBTIQ educational publications and self-help guides in Sri Lanka

- Our work is local, but our reach is global.

роЗро▓роЩрпНроХрпИропро┐ро▓рпН ро╡ро╛ро┤рпБроорпН     LGBTIQ роЪроорпВроХродрпНродро┐ройро░рпИ роЖродро░ро┐родрпНродрпБ, роЗро▓роЩрпНроХрпИ роХройроЯро╛ роЙропро░рпН родрпВродро░роХроорпН ро╡ро╛ройро╡ро┐ро▓рпН роХрпКроЯро┐ропрпИ роЙропро░рпНродрпНродро┐ропрпБро│рпНро│родрпБ.
родройрпНрокро╛ро▓рпАро░рпНрокрпНрокро┐рой, роИро░рпНрокро╛ро▓рпАро░рпНрокрпНрокро┐рой, рооро╛ро▒рпНро▒рпБрокрпНрокро╛ро▓рпАро░рпНрокрпНрокро┐рой ро╡рпЖро▒рпБрокрпНрокрпБроХрпНроХро│рпБроХрпНроХро│рпБроХрпНроХрпЖродро┐ро░ро╛рой 2021
роЪро░рпНро╡родрпЗроЪ родро┐ройродрпНродрпИ роХрпКрогрпНроЯро╛роЯрпБроХро┐ро▒родрпБ.

Our LATEST survey on LGBTIQ employeesтАЩ experiences in the workplace revealed that many of them struggle with revealing their Sexual Orientation and/or Gender Identity/Expression and being their true selves at the workplace due to discrimination and harassment.

58% of the respondents stated that they have experienced verbal harassment and 31% said they have experienced sexual harassment. 44% said they were not willing to report such harassment to the management because they fear facing more reprisals. Tragically, 23% of the respondents also mentioned leaving their jobs due to psychological and emotional harassment.

Such discrimination in workplaces compromises the economic security of LGBTIQ individuals. It is imperative to end Homophobia, Transphobia, and Biphobia in workplaces in Sri Lanka.

Read the full report: https://www.equal-ground.org/wp-content/uploads/DAP-REPORT-FINAL.pdf

CALL FOR AUDITIONS!
EQUAL GROUND is looking for actors and dancers from the LGBTIQ community in Sri Lanka to appear in a local music video project that will be also viewed internationally. 
Requirements: 
Needs to be from the LGBTIQ community and be open (as you will appear in the video).
You need to be able to commit your time and be available for the video shoot (1-2 days). 
Your participation is voluntary - no payments will be made.
You should sign a disclaimer if chosen. 
Once the video has been shot, we cannot make changes - so if you agree to participate, you cannot remove yourself once the shoot is completed. 
Sinhala and Tamil speakers are encouraged to audition. 
To apply, email your photo  and a bio to media@equalgroundsrilanka.com by 06 AUGUST 2021. 
Video will be shot with all health precautions in place.

In Sri Lanka, diverse Sexual Orientations and/or Gender Identities/Expressions are heavily marginalized, but research shows that 12% of the adult population (18 - 65 years) identify as LGBTIQ. 

What are the sentiments, challenges, and frustrations of the LGBTIQ community? How do non-LGBTIQ persons view the LGBTIQ community? 

Discussing all these issues and more, EQUAL GROUND just launched its latest report on 'Mapping LGBTIQ Identities in Sri Lanka. This is the first of its kind, covering the whole island. To read/download the full report, visit: https://www.equal-ground.org/wp-content/uploads/Report_EG-edited.pdf

2022.07.14 

To Leaders of all Political Parties and Honorable Members of Parliament

Let's not adopt any divisive measures
Let's elect the President and Prime Minister by consensus

The conduct  of some   public  representatives  indicates  that there are some who have still  not  realized  the severity  of the  present economic, political and social instability facing  Sri Lanka  and the  inalienable  obligation  they have,   as political party leaders and parliamentarians,  in  overcoming  this situation.

If we all do not work together at this moment, no one will be able to prevent you, the politicians, and us, the citizens, from plunging into a catastrophic disaster. Whoever will be elected to the power to govern the country in the future, will certainly be compelled to make unpopular decisions, and even we, the citizens too, will have to make great sacrifices though we are not directly responsible for this adversity.

Therefore, we kindly request all of you, the party leaders and Members of Parliament, to focus your attention to the following points in selecting a new President and a Prime Minister.

1. The President and the Prime Minister of the proposed Interim Government should be elected by the consensus of all political parties, and prevent conducting a poll in doing so, under any circumstances.

2. Avoid considering only the numerical majority of the respective political parties in the parliament in this exercise.

3.  Prevent from all actions and expressing opinions that may cause division or discord among political parties.

4. Put aside all personal agendas, political agendas or narrow party/power agendas and always put the priority on the country and the people.

5. Avoid making decisions targeting upcoming elections, at this difficult time
 
6. Ensure that at least one person from each political party or group represented in Parliament are included when selecting the next Cabinet.

7. Make sure that the people who can make a positive contribution towards solving the economic, social and political crises facing the country, and are capable of managing the international situation are only given priority when electing the Cabinet. Also refrain from appointing anyone who has become a victim of public displeasure. 

8. Do not decline the request if the President or Prime Minister of the forthcoming all-party government extends an invitation to you to be a   Cabinet Minister. 

We firmly believe that all political parties should pay their attention to the above matters. Also, when selecting the Cabinet, the  political parties should pay their particular attention on  appointing a team  that is  innovative,  free from conventionality,  experienced  in crisis management, and is  prepared to take  risks  are taken into account. 

Otherwise, it is inevitable that the current crisis will be   intensified further   and plunge the country into a worse predicament that it would not be possible for the country to recover and restore easily.

Rohana Hettiarachi
Executive Director

08-06-2022

тАЬCandidates indulged in offering bribes and dole-outs are liable to lose their Council MembershipтАЭ. The Appeal against Moneragala landmark judgment dismissed.
The Appeal filed in the Supreme Court against the judgment given by the Monaragala High Court on  the election petition case on  13th September  last year  that marked  a significant milestone in the history of electoral history  in Sri Lanka was withdrawn yesterday (07th June ).

The Appeal in question was filed, with the guidance and assistance of the PAFFREL by a candidate who contested the local government elections held in 2018 for Maduraketiya Ward of Monaragala Pradeshiya Sabha, alleging that the candidate who won the election had indulged in offering bribes to the voters during the election time.

 Accordingly, Monaragala High Court Judge Ranga Dissanayake pronounced the verdict on September 13 last year abolishing the councillorship of Tharanga Harshaka Dissanayake, the respondent of the case who won the electoral seat of Maduruketiya division of Monaragala Pradeshiya Sabah and ordered that W.M. Sunil, the defeated candidate of the UNP be appointed to the vacant post.

The appeal filed by the petitioner, the respondent of the above case in the Supreme Court challenging the verdict given by Moneragala High Courth as been withdrawn by petitionerтАЩs Counsel on 7th June stating that he would not be interested in proceeding with the Appeal.

This judgment will prove to be a unique and historic one,  since it will lead to persuade the  candidates to refrain from  bribing the  voters in future elections (local government, provincial council, parliamentary elections and presidential elections).Even if a candidate secures a Council Membership offering bribes to voters, a precedent has now been set up by this  judgment that the Council Membership of his/her is liable to be  abolished and other punishments imposed  in the event an aggrieved party files an election petition challenging his/her election.

Also this case has reaffirmed the need for limiting candidate spending and holding elections in a free and fair atmosphere.

The responsibility of taking further action in keeping with this judgment lies with the President and the Election Commission, and we hope that those decisions will be implemented soon.
Moreover, following the precedent created by this judgment,the PAFFRELis looking forward to continuing take legal action against the parties indulged in fraudulent activities in future elections.

Rohana Hettiarachchie
Executive Director

HAPPY LESBIAN VISIBILITY DAY 2020!
.
No one should be judged for who they love.
Unfortunately, the lesbian community faces a range of challenges rooted in homophobia and rampant sexism. Worse, these issues are often invisible or ignored.
EQUAL GROUND is proud to celebrate and support all lesbians тАУ no matter how you choose to present yourselves тАУ today and every day.
We see you, we stand with you, and we love you!
HAPPY LESBIAN VISIBILITY DAY 2020!
.

Every year on May 17th, the International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia (IDAHOBIT) is observed across the world in more than 130 countries, including 37 countries where consensual same-sex acts are illegal.

We start our 16 days campaign against GBV (Gender Based Violence) with a preview of  тАЬMy Rights, My ResponsibilityтАЭ - a publication to be launched by EQUAL GROUND on 10th December 2019, International Human Rights Day. 
The booklet in Sinhala, Tamil, and English, focuses on the rights and laws that affect the LGBTIQ community in Sri Lanka. Through this publication, EQUAL GROUND aims to provide information to the LGBTIQ community on the laws that affect our community and the rights we are entitled to as Sri Lankan citizens. Most importantly, it gives the reader information on how to protect themselves when faced with rights violations of any type. 

#16DaysOfActivism #OrangeTheWorld #GenerationEquality #LGBT #LKR

The Cabinet of Ministers has appointed an Expert Committee to
prepare the draft of the proposed Second Republican Constitution of
Sri Lanka.

The Committee has already commenced the process of receiving the
ideas and suggestions of the Public, and you will have the opportunity
to submit your suggestions to the Committee in Sinhala, Tamil or
English on following topics.

* The nature of the State
* Fundamental rights
* Language issue
* Principles of Guiding Government Policy
* The Executive (President / Cabinet / Public Service)
* The Legislature
* Elections, including the right to vote and referendum
* Decentralization / devolution of power / separation of powers
* The Judiciary
* Public Finance
* State security
* Any other relevant subject not specified above

Write down your suggestions briefly; type them on an A4 size sheet
using a separate sheet for each topic and send to the following
address by registered post, on or before 30 November.

Room 32 (Block 02)
Bandaranaike Memorial International Conference Hall,
Bauddhaloka Mawatha,
Colombo 07

Or

To the email address indicated below.

expertscommpublic@yahoo.com

As the aspirations of all sections of the society should be represented in the Constitution, please be a partner in this national endeavor by submitting your valuable ideas and suggestions.

Today, Sri Lanka  Police Academy in colloboration with Equite Sri Lanka started the second series of training and sensation programs for the in service Police officers on the Rights of the LGBTIQ+ community, Law and Human rights.

#Dignity #Diversity #Policing #EquiteSriLanka #Policetraining #Justice #Law #advocacy

The National Police Academy organized a series of training programs for 606 chief inspectors across all Police Stations in Sri Lanka. 

Equite Sri Lanka was invited conduct a sensetization session to participated Police Officers on LGBTIQ+ community especially on ethical conducts in carrying out services to LGBTIQ+ community members, which will make a big difference in the protection and promotion of rights of the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka.

The year 2023 can be considered a vital year for the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka. The highlights of the year include the Supreme Court's special determination on decriminalizing consensual same-sex relationships and the initiatives taken by Sri Lanka Police to ensure the rights of the LGBTIQ+ community. 

We are delighted to share with you some of the initiatives we have carried out in 2023 as ├Йquit├й Sri Lanka among work related to community engagement, research, advocacy work, sensitization and awareness-raising programs. 

Join us in our efforts to protect and promote the rights of the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka in the year 2024.

Today, Sri Lanka  Police Academy started the first ever series of training and sensation programs for the in service Police officers on the Rights of the LGBTIQ+ community.

Gracing the opening ceremony, the Chairperson of the Sri Lanka Human Rights Commission, Honourable Chief Justice LBT Dehideniya, on behalf of the Inspector General of Police (Act) of Sri Lanka, Mr. Asanga Karavita, Senior Deputy Inspector General, training and higher training, Acting Ambassador of the Embassy of Kingdoms of Netherlands in Sri Lanka, his excellency Iwan Rugtens, DIG Renuka Jayasundara, Cheif of Police Women and Children Division and Focul point for LGBTIQ+ community and trainers of the program joined hands with us.

We see this as a milestone in empowering the LGBTIQ+ movement as we advocate and promote inclusive policies towards the LGBTIQ+ community within Sri Lanka Police.

Moments that enlightened and ignited change! ЁЯМИ Our event, 'Way to Decriminalization,' brought together brilliant minds and passionate voices to discuss the vital journey towards equality and decriminalization for the Sri Lankan LGBTIQ+ community. 

A heartfelt thank you to our incredible panelists and moderators who made our 'Way to Decriminalization' event a resounding success! Your insights, expertise, and dedication have truly inspired us and illuminated the path towards equal rights for all. Together, we stand stronger in our commitment to the cause of equality and justice. Thank you for being the catalysts of change! ЁЯП│я╕ПтАНЁЯМИ

├Йquit├й Sri Lanka has officially launched its presence in Nuwara Eliya.

├Йquit├й Sri Lanka is dedicated towards building a better environment for all regardless of their gender identities, expressions and sexual orientations. We main focus lies in advocating towards the Rights of LGBTIQ+ individuals and sexual and reproductive health while creating awareness on fundamental rights and sexual and reproductive health. 

We are greatly excited to announce our expansion of work in Central Province and the opening of a community center in the Nuwara Eliya area. We aim to work closely with the LGBTIQ+ community living in Central Province while networking with the organisations within the region to facilitate knowledge sharing, capacity development, and collaborative efforts among these organizations.

Join us in our commitment to fostering inclusivity, advocacy, and empowerment within the Central Province and beyond.

Fifth Training of Trainers Program. Northern Province.
In the process of providing quality training on social, sexual and reproductive health rights for young peer leaders covering the 9 provinces of Sri Lanka.
Through this two-day training and the information booklet provided to these peer leaders, we hope to create positive attitudes, disseminate correct information and create a change in social attitude in the society about the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka.
Location- Kilinochchi

Fourth Training of Trainers Program. North Central Province.
In the process of providing quality training on social, sexual and reproductive health rights for young peer leaders covering the 9 provinces of Sri Lanka.
Through this two-day training and the information booklet provided to these peer leaders, we hope to create positive attitudes, disseminate correct information and create a change in social attitude in the society about the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka.
Location- Anuradhapura

First Training of Trainers Program. North West Province.

In the process of providing quality training on social, sexual and reproductive health rights for young peer leaders covering the 9 provinces of Sri Lanka.

Through this two-day training and the information booklet provided to these peer leaders, we hope to create positive attitudes, disseminate correct information and create a change in social attitude in the society about the LGBTIQ+ community living in Sri Lanka.

Location- Nomadic School, Kurunegala

The initial phase of preparing the first situation analysis report on the transgender male community has thus begun.

The report aims to identify the key challenges of the community with the objective of developing necessary advocacy, communication and work strategies to meet those needs and get the active participation of the community in the policy-making process.

Breaking away from the traditional information-gathering methods, we, Equite Sri Lanka, Prana Transgender Network and Sri Lankan Pride Team created a more comfortable platform for the community members which encouraged them to share their experiences, thoughts and suggestions on the unique challenges and issues faced by the community. These interventions within this Pride month give us the motivation to carry forward our work in the fight towards LGBTIQ+ Rights in Sri Lanka. 

We wholeheartedly extended our gratitude towards everyone who joined us in raising a voice for the rights of all of us and the voiceless.

The initial phase of preparing the first situation analysis report on the transgender male community has thus begun.

The report aims to identify the key challenges of the community with the objective of developing necessary advocacy, communication and work strategies to meet those needs and get the active participation of the community in the policy-making process.

Breaking away from the traditional information-gathering methods, we, Equite Sri Lanka, Prana Transgender Network and Sri Lankan Pride Team created a more comfortable platform for the community members which encouraged them to share their experiences, thoughts and suggestions on the unique challenges and issues faced by the community. These interventions within this Pride month give us the motivation to carry forward our work in the fight towards LGBTIQ+ Rights in Sri Lanka. 
H
We wholeheartedly extended our gratitude towards everyone who joined us in raising a voice for the rights of all of us and the voiceless.

The initial phase of preparing the first situation analysis report on the transgender male community has thus begun.

The report aims to identify the key challenges of the community with the objective of developing necessary advocacy, communication and work strategies to meet those needs and get the active participation of the community in the policy-making process.

Breaking away from the traditional information-gathering methods, we, Equite Sri Lanka, Prana Transgender Network and Sri Lankan Pride Team created a more comfortable platform for the community members which encouraged them to share their experiences, thoughts and suggestions on the unique challenges and issues faced by the community. These interventions within this Pride month give us the motivation to carry forward our work in the fight towards LGBTIQ+ Rights in Sri Lanka. 

We wholeheartedly extended our gratitude towards everyone who joined us in raising a voice for the rights of all of us and the voiceless.

├Йquit├й Sri Lanka Media Fellowship Programme.

If you are a person who creates attractive content in electronic media, print media including newspapers or social media including YouTube, blogs, and websites, then this opportunity is for you.

If you are interested in creating content related to the LGBTIQ+ community, their struggles, and rights, and would like to receive a two-day residential training on the LGBTIQ+ community and media, send us your application form.

An expert panel designated by ├Йquit├й Sri Lanka will examine your application form, and 25 of the most competitive participants will be recruited for the two-day training program. After the training you can submit Concept Notes to create content for a period of three months. Financial grants will be awarded to 10 best concept notes.

Designers who receive financial grants are guided by a panel of experts, and our organisation will promote and boost your designs.

The first phase of the training program will be conducted in Sinhala Medium.

Submit your application form from the link below.
https://forms.gle/6o1w5CzzXQZ7ykCB7
Deadline - 2023.10.13

A Heart felt Award from the LGBTIQ+ community. 

It is with humble pride that we share with you that Equite Sri Lanka was awarded as the most supportive organization at the recently held Rainbow Art Festival in Batticaloa. This award received from the Tamil-speaking LGBTIQ+ community is special to our organization because it is an appreciation for the humanitarian efforts we are taking against racism, bigotry and sexism, along side the fight for the rights of the LGBTIQ+ community. Thank you to all of you who believe in us!

├Йquit├й Sri Lanka Media Fellowship Programme.

If you are a person who creates attractive content in electronic media, print media including newspapers or social media including YouTube, blogs, and websites, then this opportunity is for you.

If you are interested in creating content related to the LGBTIQ+ community, their struggles, and rights, and would like to receive a two-day residential training on the LGBTIQ+ community and media, send us your application form.

An expert panel designated by ├Йquit├й Sri Lanka will examine your application form, and 25 of the most competitive participants will be recruited for the two-day training program. After the training you can submit Concept Notes to create content for a period of three months. Financial grants will be awarded to 10 best concept notes.

Designers who receive financial grants are guided by a panel of experts, and our organisation will promote and boost your designs.

The first phase of the training program will be conducted in Sinhala Medium.

Submit your application form from the link below.
https://forms.gle/6o1w5CzzXQZ7ykCB7
Deadline - 2023.10.08

In this radiant season, we stand united in celebrating Pride, embracing love, and championing equality. We defy prejudice, break barriers, and uplift marginalized voices while creating a world where everyone is free to love and be their authentic selves. In our diversity lies our strength, and in our unity lies our power to inspire change. Let us stand hand in hand, hearts ablaze with compassion, and continue to fight for a future that is inclusive and accepting. Love knows no bounds, and together, we rise to create a world where all are celebrated and respected. Happy Pride Month! ЁЯМИтЭд

The power of words can both heal and harm. Hate speech against the LGBTIQ+ community is a weapon that inflicts deep wounds, undermining their dignity, rights, and well-being. On IDAHOT 2023, let us raise our voices against hate and ignorance, fostering a world where love, acceptance, and equality flourish for all.

Yesterday (2023.04.17) a petition was submitted to the Supreme Court against the private member's motion presented by Member of Parliament Premnath C Dolawatta to ammend Sections 365 and  repeal 365a of the Penal Code introduced by the British law in 1883 considering homosexuality as a crime. An interlocutory petition against the petition, which spreads hatred and fear against LGBTIQ+ community, was presented to the Hon'ble Supreme Court by Equite Sri Lanka's Chairman Thushara Manoj and Executive Director Adhil Suraj Vimukti today.

The hearing on the petitions is scheduled to be held on April 20 by a panel of three judges.

On behalf of Equite Sri Lanka, President's Counsel Mr. Prashantalal De Alwis is scheduled to appear at the hearing of this petition.

Interlocutory petitioners

Thushara Manoj, Chairman, Equite Sri Lanka
Adhil Suraj , Executive Director Equite Sri Lanka

On International Women's Day 2023, let's celebrate the remarkable strength, courage, and resilience of all women around the world. 

While celebrating the incredible accomplishments of women worldwide, it is also evident that the fight for gender equality is far from over. It calls to reflect on the importance of inclusivity in promoting gender equality at all layers. 

We are living in the era of technology where everything is at the grab of our fingertips.  Eventhough there is a massive technological advancement, the progression of gender equality, especially within digital spaces is yet to be accomplished. Achieving true gender equality requires creating a world where all individuals are free to express their gender and sexuality without fear of discrimination or marginalization, in particular to all women with diverse gender identities, expressions and sexual orientations. Therefore it is important to recognize and advocate for the rights of LGBTIQ+  within the digital space to create a more just and equitable world for all individuals.

You may remember Equite Sri Lanka's study on the need for justice in the LGBTIQ+ community. The study was conducted through online media and focus group discussions with community members in 6 provinces and online suvey covering all provinces. In addition, several targeted community groups also joined the discussion.

#queeradvocacy #queerrights #legalneedassessment #law #repealthelaw 

This is the final stage of that report. Equite Sri Lanka prepared a needs assessment report based on the information gathered through the discussions and online survey.

Responding to the UK, the US, Canada, and Norway urging Sri Lanka to decriminalize same-sex relationships by repealing Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code, Minister of Foreign Affairs, PresidentтАЩs Counsel (PC) M.U.M. Ali Sabry stated yesterday (9) that while the Government would decriminalize the same, same-sex marriages would not be legalized. 

Speaking to The Daily Morning, Ali Sabry said: тАЬThere is a Private Member Bill initiated by Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP) Government MP and Attorney Premnath C. Dolawatte. The Government will support its position of decriminalising same-sex relationships. We are, however, not legalising same-sex marriages. But, we would decriminalise it. I think that there is a lot of consensus for that, so let that come to Parliament.тАЭ

When queried as to whether Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code would be repealed, Ali Sabry said: тАЬYes. ThatтАЩs correct. Decriminalising it would be added.тАЭ

Last year (2022), a Bill to amend the Penal Code with the aim of protecting the rights of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer and questioning (LGBTIQ) communities in Sri Lanka was handed over to President Ranil Wickremesinghe by Dolawatte.

Dolawatte told The Daily Morning yesterday that the draft Bill to amend Sections 365 and 365A of the Penal Code by decriminalising the offences had been referred to the Attorney GeneralтАЩs (AG) Department to clarify consistency with the Constitution.

#UPR #UNHRC #UN #UNMechanism #Equite #Queer #repealthelaw

Sri Lanka's 4th Cycle on Universal Periodic Review took place today, 1st February 2023 from 09.00 a.m.тАУ 12.30 p.m. (Geneva Time) in Room 20 at the Palais des Nations in Geneva. Following the country report presented by the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr Ali Sabry, The member states provided recommendations to Sri Lanka on its Human Rights Situation. 

Among the Recommendations, It was seen that many countries focused on concerns with regard to discrimination and violence based on gender, especially with regard to the LGBTIQ+ persons living in Sri Lanka. Countries such as the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Uruguay, Costa Rica, Canada, etc urged the government to repeal 365 and 365A of the penal code which criminalizes same-sex conduct. Recommendations were also made to ban conversion therapies on LGBTIQ+ persons while complying with the Convention Against Torture  and adopting measures to eliminate all forms of discrimination in access to health services and medicines, other social services and institutions for vulnerable groups. 

As a part of the LGBTIQ+ community in Sri Lanka, we thank all the states who made recommendations to uplift the livelihoods of LGBTIQ+ persons in Sri Lanka. We look forward to seeing the response of the government in adopting these recommendations and we intend to push forward the movement in ensuring the Rights of the LGBTIQ+ Community within Sri Lanka.

Keep in touch with Equite Sri Lanka.

роорпВро▓роорпН https://www.un.org/en/coronavirus/what-is-domestic-abuse

Domestic violence also known as intimate part violence is not a myth. Most people assume that domestic violence can found only in heterosexual relationships against women but this has widely spread and anyone can be a victim of domestic violence including men in heterosexual relationships and anyone from SOGIE community.
"Domestic violence" or "intimate partner violence", can be defined as a pattern of behavior in any relationship that is used to gain or maintain power and control over an intimate partner. 
This can be psychological actions or threats of actions that influence another person. This includes any behaviors that frighten, intimidate, hurt, humiliate, blame, manipulate or wound someone. 
Domestic violence can happen to anyone regardless of their race, age, sexual orientation, religion, or gender. It can occur within a range of relationships including couples who are married, living together or dating or this can occur within the family, relatives or parent-child relationship. 
Source https://www.un.org/en/coronavirus/what-is-domestic-abuse

Celebrating the Sri Lankan Pride we, the LGBTIQ community invite you to join us for the screening and discussion of PRIDE movie on 28th June 2022 from 6.30 pm onwards at Teargas Cinema, Gotagogama. 

It is with great urge we emphasize the importance of a collective movement to strengthen the struggle to create a society where everyone can live with PRIDE. 

Please note that no food or beverages are allowed within the cinema. We kindly request you adhere to this as a respect to the space and its maintenance. 

Hope to see you there! Let's stand in Solidarity!

Anyone who recognise, identify and express themselves as a woman, is indeed a woman. No one can question it. Celebrate all women who have identified themselves as women. Let's respect the diversity of women.

It is widely seen that many LGBTIQ community members are directly or indirectly forced into marriage due to the social values and stigma. The family pressure is majorly seen therefore community members easily become victims of mental abuse. As these traumas could lead to many psychological instabilities, it is important for the individuals to have self value and self love.

You are not guilty.
It is not wrong to try to get out of a violent relationship. You will not become a swindler or a selfish person by trying like that. You have the right to get rid of another headache. There is no good in being in a painful relationship. There is only one meaning when you come out of such a relationship, it is that you are a loving soul who loves you, who cares about you.
It is not your fault that a violent partner is abusive,
What an abusive partner often says is that I do this entirely because of your fault. But the real story here is that there can be many reasons for a violent partner to become abusive, but none of these are your responsibility. He has no right to harass you for not acting his way. You are looking for a life partner, not a disciplinary center.
You are an adult mature enough to make your own decisions,
You may need help making decisions in your life, yes we all really need help at some point in life. But that does not mean that you should be left to fend for yourself. A relationship is a journey together. Walking together does not mean allowing yourself to be overwhelmed.
First and foremost, do not allow yourself to be overwhelmed by the guilt that hurts you inside.
If you need help, ask for help. do not be afraid.
You can call us anytime.
We will not leave you. So don't leave yourself.
If you have a domestic relationship, keep your essentials in a convenient place where you can get them quickly.
Get help as soon as you get a chance, get help and leave.

Prevention of Domestic Violence Act No. 34 of 2005

This gives anyone who is a victim of domestic violence in this country the opportunity to apply for a protection order from a Magistrate's Court against the perpetrator for any violence that may or may not be committed against them.
The court has the right to grant this as a security order as well as as an interim injunction while the case is being heard.
A security decree will always prevent the perpetrator from committing an act of violence as well as ensuring the safety of the victim.
Article 11 of the Act sets out the types of prohibitions that can be imposed by such a protection order, and we can see that it seeks to prevent the persecution of the oppressed from coming near the oppressed and to stop the persecution.

Going beyond this, when someone gets the protection of this Act, that will not block the arena to claim their rights by filing another civil or criminal case.

The most important point in this bill is that the words 'spouse' and 'partner' are used here. Then this Act has allowed us to seek legal redressal whether we have a marital relationship or not.

Sadly, having sex with people of different sexual identities and inclinations is still a criminal offense under Sri Lankan law, increasing the likelihood that they will not be able to obtain such protection.

So why we delay to come in front for our own protection and our own rights?

Equite Sri Lanka successfully held the National Level Stakeholders discussion on disseminating the Midterm report submitted on the LGBTIQ chapter for Universal Periodic Review. The event was held on 24th June 2022 at Radisson Hotel with the participation of Hon. Hirunika Premachandra and representatives from President Legal unit, President secretarial, UN, Department of Prison, Legal Aid Commission, Bar Association, National STD/AIDS Control Programme, Family Health Bureau, The Family Planning Association of Sri Lanka, National Child Protection Authority, Protect Union, University of Colombo and Human Right Activists. 

The discussion was based on the finding of the report and the contribution of the stakeholders toward creating a National level action plan to push forward policy changes.  The discussion was very fruitful and was facilitated by Ms Ambika Satkunanathan and Equite Team.

International Day of the Girl Child is celebrated on 11 October, and this year the theme will be тАЬMy voice, Our equal futureтАЭ. It is known that homosexual, bisexual and transgender children in Sri Lanka does not have equal opportunities. Join us to ensure that these marginalized girl children have equal opportunities through changed attitudes, comprehensive sexuality education and respect for one another.

A person must be allowed to follow what he/she desires and according to their ability. By forcing them to take other paths, their very future can be bleak. Their gender can never be determined by the subjects they study. By letting them to follow the path they want, one day they will be a useful person to society, shining all over the world. By obstructing, by exhausting physically as well as mentally, they will be lost where they are and will be lost in society.

'Step into their world in order to have an empathetic and connected conversation'

In a Sri Lankan context, parents of queer youth have a difficult time accepting their children for who they are. Parents refuse to acknowledge the existence and usage of terms like 'gay', 'lesbian and 'transgender' in itself that they have an even more difficult time if their children belong to the LGBTQ community. There is so much stigma attached still.
 
Rejecting your child because of who they want to love and who they want to be can cause significant implications for that child's health and well being, sometimes resulting in depression and suicide.
Coming out is a lifelong journey of understanding and acknowledging one's gender identity/sexual orientation. Let's make it a pleasant one.

Do you know? That the death penalty was imposed in 1962 as a punishment for being homosexual or transgender? To rescue the community from that, homosexuality and transgender were included in the list of mental illnesses. And that the World Health Organization (WHO) in 1992 removed homosexuality and transgender from the list of mental illnesses, stating that it was not a mental illness but a natural phenomenon. You have the right to object to any doctor or psychiatrist who is trying to seduce, hypnotize or cure you.

IDAHOT or The International Day against Homophobia and Transphobia is important to us for two reasons. First, because this day is an opportunity to commemorate the same sex, Transgender and other queer communities that have been killed, beaten, wronged and deprived of opportunities throughout history.

Secondly, this International Day can be used to raise awareness and unite to create a society free of homophobia and Transphobia.

Together we will eradicate the Homophobia and Transphobia!

The basic foundation for maintaining dominance falls from home. Dominance in group activities, outdoor activities, and office is often carried out in violation of ethical principles, trampling other. But the right dominance is to build the dominance of an exemplary character by keeping the people around him happy, setting an example to the society, helping others and showing respect. True domination is not violence but dignity.
