Anger is an emotion that any human should learn to control or handle. ItтАЩs not part of being a man or becoming masculine. What men have learnt is how they should behave and respond when they are angry. Which is harmful for others as well as themselves most of the time. LetтАЩs create a learning culture where men and boys are taught to manage harmful emotions like anger in a non violent way and where men and boys leant to challenge the learnings which promote harmful emotions in men.

Men and boys have not been properly taught to embrace love and compassion as much as they have been taught to become violent or respond violently in situations of conflict. In the frame of masculinity, тАШlove and compassionтАЩ had not been treated as male strengths. LetтАЩs support our sonтАЩs, brothers, friends partners, and companions to embrace love and compassion and reject violence.

Equite is ready to launch a photo campaign about 'Men and Masculinity'.
We as a society have a loose definition of what it means to be a man. We characterize man as the opposite of women. However, this definition is actually how we define toxic masculinity. Masculinity (manhood or manliness) is a set of attributes, behaviors, and roles associated with men and boys. Masculinity is a notion which is socially constructed and men feel superior over women, dominant which is called patriarchy. 
Here we asked the youth community what 'masculinity' is, allowing them to define it in a single word.
According to their definition of being a man or what masculinity is, we thought to present this to you.

IDAHOT or The International Day against  Homophobia and Transphobia is important to us for two reasons. First, because this day is an opportunity to commemorate the same sex, Transgender and other queer  communities that have been killed, beaten, wronged and deprived of opportunities throughout history. 

Secondly, this International Day can be used to raise awareness and unite to create a society free of homophobia and Transphobia.

Together we will eradicate the Homophobia and Transphobia!

Countries all over band together on International Women's Day to celebrate the achievements of women and campaign for gender equality. 
This time Equite Sri Lanka is going to celebrate IWD virtually by raising the most inspirational voices of social activists in Sri Lanka to show they choose to challenge and call out inequity.

"We can actively choose to challenge stereotypes, fight bias, broaden perceptions, improve situations, and celebrate women's achievements,"
"Collectively, each one of us can help create a gender-equal world. Let's all be #EachforEqual."

#choosetochallenge #IWD2021 #Genderinequality #genderbias

Countries all over band together on International Women's Day to celebrate the achievements of women and campaign for gender equality. 
This time Equite Sri Lanka is going to celebrate IWD virtually by raising the most inspirational voices of social activists in Sri Lanka to show they choose to challenge and call out inequity.

"We can actively choose to challenge stereotypes, fight bias, broaden perceptions, improve situations, and celebrate women's achievements,"
"Collectively, each one of us can help create a gender equal world. Let's all be #EachforEqual."

Countries all over band together on International Women's Day to celebrate the achievements of women and campaign for gender equality. 
This time Equite Sri Lanka is going to celebrate IWD virtually by raising the most inspirational voices of social activists in Sri Lanka to show they choose to challenge and call out inequity.

"We can actively choose to challenge stereotypes, fight bias, broaden perceptions, improve situations, and celebrate women's achievements,"
"Collectively, each one of us can help create a gender equal world. Let's all be #EachforEqual."

#choosetochallenge #IWD2021 #Genderinequality #genderbias

Sri Lanka LGBTIQ Pride 2020
LetтАЩs dedicate this yearтАЩs Sri Lanka LGBTIQ Pride to celebrate the lives of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex and questioning community, while maintaining the social distance.
We have organised a event and we invite you to send your Pride themed entries to us, to spread positive attitudes among Sri Lankans about the Pride.
Details
- Singing, dancing, acting, playing instruments and speaking
Duration тАУ 3 minutes
Please keep in mind to use only mobile phones.
We encourage LGBTIQ-themed entries. 
- Drawings, poems, short stories, letters, animated videos and photos 
Theme тАУ Sri Lanka LGBTIQ Pride
Send clear photos of your work.
Along with your work, you can also send a positive message about the LGBTIQ Pride. You are welcome to send your photo. 
Your entries and messages will be posted on Equite Sri Lanka Facebook page with your name or chosen name and your photo (with your consent).
Deadline: 24th June 2020
Anyone who supports the LGBTIQ community can take part in this event.
How to submit your entry:
Name of chosen name - 
Whether youтАЩre an LGBTIQ person or an ally -
A photo of yourself, if you like - 
WhatasApp number тАУ 0711 38 46 39
Email address тАУ equitesrilanka2019@gmail.com
Please state тАЬSri Lanka LGBTIQ Pride 2020тАЭ in the subject line.
Happy Pride!
#Srilankanpride2020
#Onlinepride

#insolidarity

Countries all over band together on International Women's Day to celebrate the achievements of women and campaign for gender equality. 

This time Equite Sri Lanka is going to celebrate IWD virtually by raising the most inspirational voices of social activists in Sri Lanka to show they choose to challenge and call out inequity.

"We can actively choose to challenge stereotypes, fight bias, broaden perceptions, improve situations, and celebrate women's achievements,"

"Collectively, each one of us can help create a gender equal world. Let's all be #EachforEqual."

Sensitization of Stakeholders in Region on Gender, Sexual orientation and Human rights Ampara District Sri Lanka 

Equite Sri Lanka has commenced sensitization activities in each district targeting various government stakeholders. 
Police officers, Governors, Grama Niladhari, Members of local government, School teachers,religious leaders, Counselors,Development officers, Doctors and others stakeholders who engage with the LGBTIQ Community.

This time the consultation, been carried out by the Equite Sri Lanka in Ampara district. The sensitization program is anchored on the theme "Marginalized Community, Human Rights & Law". The program Facilitated by Chanthuru Thiveegan at #Ampara.

Journalists need to be more sensitive when it comes to handling media about the LGBTIQ community. Through audio-visual media as well as social media, ideas are presented that do not fit the characters of the LGBTIQ community. I urge the media, its leaders and journalists not to make ppublications by ridiculing the homosexual  community and the transgender  community.

Human rights activist
Manju Hemal

I am a victim of social media violence. You Tubers spread a lot of unwanted stories about me. I was bullied on social media. But none of that made me feel bad or affected the things I adopted. But one good thing happened in my life. I am a proud, courageous person who came forward in a country like Sri Lanka. 

Mr.Ram Dulip Mister Sri Lanka for Mister Earth International 2018.

We condemn the YouTube channels that sell the LGBTIQ community for their own publicity.

Currently, there seems to be a massive crackdown on the LGBTIQ community using social media networks such as Facebook and YouTube. You can also see how social media networks can be used for the benefit of the LGBTIQ community. Let's assemble for a change.

Transgender sexual encounter in Dambulla? 

The manner in which the media has reported the death of a man with a transgender social identity, who had been brutally murdered in the Dambulla area is disgraceful. Deceased was insulted using various words such as male sex worker, a man who disguised as a woman, dressed as a woman, etc., and the things were reported in a way that bring hatred towards him and the LGBTIQ community. Let's condemn the disgraceful reporting of black market journalists.

The homosexual and transgender community in Sri Lanka faces certain problems, the media does not care about their privacy and publishes in a way that harms them, especially those who lose their jobs and educational opportunities.

We urge all media institutions, media activists and social media activists to always respect the right to self-respect, privacy and equality of their community when publishing information about homosexual and transgender people in Sri Lanka.

Media organizations and journalists are at the forefront of groups that spread falsehoods and hatred against the LGBTIQ community. Among the minority of journalists who report sensitively and ethically, the majority do so by spreading hatred and insults. This time we have chosen to celebrate International Human Rights Day to share with you how the media is being used against the LGBTIQ community and what action needs to be taken.

There are a lot of myths and misconceptions in Sri LankaтАЩs society about women and men. Some of these myths affect peopleтАЩs mental health, and some people even go on to commit suicide. We at Equite Sri Lanka are launching a social media campaign today with the aim of eradicating these misconceptions

#р╖Гр╖Тр╢║р╢╜р╖Фр╢╕р╢пр╖Щр╢▒р╖Пр╖Гр╢╕р╖Пр╢▒р╖Пр╢нр╖Кр╖Ар╢║р╖Ар╖Щр╢▒р╖Фр╖Ар╖Щр╢▒р╖К"

Countries all over band together on International Women's Day to celebrate the achievements of women and campaign for gender equality. 

This time Equite Sri Lanka is going to celebrate IWD virtually by raising the most inspirational voices of social activists in Sri Lanka to show they choose to challenge and call out inequity.

"We can actively choose to challenge stereotypes, fight bias, broaden perceptions, improve situations, and celebrate women's achievements,"
"Collectively, each one of us can help create a gender-equal world. Let's all be #EachforEqual."

#choosetochallenge #IWD2021 #Genderinequality #genderbias

A tremendous workload is ahead of us who accept and celebrate the diversity as fair and reasonable human beings.  Let's get together to break the enforced silence on LGBTIQA+ community and eliminate homophobia, transphobia and biphobia in Sri Lanka. 

Radika Gunaratne
Attorney-at-Law,
Activist and journalist

On  May 17, International Day against Homophobia, Biphobia and Transphobia we will take the space that is rightfully ours, because our voices, our stories, our lived realities matter!

By all coming together on one global day, our тАЬnoiseтАЭ will be so loud that all our LGBTQI+++ sisters and brothers all over the world who cannot speak up will hear the sound of hope and solidarity

The Transgender community is alien to Sinhala Buddhist culture, Christian Catholicism and Islam, but not to Hindu culture. This is because in Hindu culture it is believed that a transgender person is a combination of "Ardhanarisvara" or Shiva and Parvati.

There are many misconceptions about what the LGBTIQ community is asking for. Fighting for the freedom of their sexuality is understood by many as a demand to have sex anywhere with those they see. We are lined up to eliminate such misconceptions. Respect to privacy.

Description of Tasks

- Analyze user behaviour on social media with special reference to the spread of disinformation, hate speech and online gender-based violence on social media platforms. 

- Draft reports based on the findings.

- Conduct training and workshops for key stakeholders.

- Assist the programme functions of the organization, as and when required.

Today is the International Day to End Violence against Women and so marks first day of 16 days of Activism against Gender-Based Violence (GBV)

Hashtag Generation will explore several gender-based stereotypes and myths that lead to deeply structural and systemic forms of sexual and gender-based violence in our societies and communities.

Tune in every day at 7 PM to debunk various gender-based myths and stereotypes with us.

Previous court orders have granted permission to pilgrims of any religion to engage in religious activities within the Kurunthur Malai religious site. Based on these court orders the Department of Archaeology has allowed the trustee board of the Adisivan Aiyanar Hindu Temple of Kutruthur to hold a Pongal festival at the Kurundi Vihara shrine in Kurunthur Malai, a site reserved for Hindu religious ceremonies.

The prevailing notion is that youth shapes our future. Yet, we consistently overlook that young people are living their reality in the present, not merely in the future.

In Sri Lanka, a notable portion of the population, mostly young people, remains disconnected from political processes, leaving them with limited voice and influence over decisions that impact their lives and communities.  Amidst leaders perpetuating injustice and corruption, the silence of most adults puts the lives and safety of young persons at risk.

Incorporating diverse political engagement is not just a basic democratic right, but also essential for establishing stable, peaceful nations and crafting policies that cater to the requirements of younger generations. The authorities must actively promote the involvement of young people in decision-making processes across all levels, ensuring their voices are elevated, not silenced. Let them lead and let their voices be heard!
